articles.headline: Why Wall St. Journal Editors Held News of Murdoch Bid
articles.snippet: Paul E. Steiger, the paper’s top editor who knew of Rupert Murdoch’s offer, is said to have decided not to publish any news of it.
articles.abstract: Paul E. Steiger, the paper’s top editor who knew of Rupert Murdoch’s offer, is said to have decided not to publish any news of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the trickiest things for a news organization to do is cover itself.
articles.byline: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and RICHARD PÉREZ PEÑA

articles.headline: East Coast Money Lent Out West
articles.snippet: A partnership between subprime lenders and Wall Street banks has now degenerated into a cross-country blame game.
articles.abstract: A partnership between subprime lenders and Wall Street banks has now degenerated into a cross-country blame game.
articles.lead_paragraph: AGOURA HILLS, Calif.  Visitors to Ownit Mortgage Solutions’ offices here are met by an abandoned reception desk and three dying potted plants that appear to have gone months without water.

articles.headline: ‘Top Chef’ Dreams Crushed by Student Loan Debt
articles.snippet: For would-be top chefs, there are few jobs that pay enough for them to retire their student loans.
articles.abstract: For would-be top chefs, there are few jobs that pay enough for them to retire their student loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rick Park started working at a Jack in the Box in Austin, Tex., when he was 18. He moved on to sub shops, pizza parlors and chain restaurants, turning out hundreds of meals during a shift.

articles.headline: A Sheik and His Uninvited ‘Guests’ Mirror Uneasy Iraq-U.S. Ties
articles.snippet: An Iraqi sheik stops by his old villa, which has been turned into a military base, to ask for his home back.
articles.abstract: An Iraqi sheik stops by his old villa, which has been turned into a military base, to ask for his home back.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUWAYBA, Iraq  Nearly every day, the sheik stops by the villa that was once his home, but is now an American garrison. Sometimes he comes with tips about the insurgency, or with news of political developments in this rural village near the Euphrates River.

articles.headline: 50 Years Later, Little Rock Can’t Escape Race
articles.snippet: An Arkansas school district is still riven by racial conflict, and some question how much progress has been made.
articles.abstract: An Arkansas school district is still riven by racial conflict, and some question how much progress has been made.
articles.lead_paragraph: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. — Fifty years after the epic desegregation struggle at Central High School, the school district here is still riven by racial conflict, casting a pall on this year’s ambitious commemorative efforts.

articles.headline: Chevron Seen Settling Case on Iraq Oil
articles.snippet: Chevron is preparing to acknowledge that it should have known oil kickbacks were being paid to Saddam Hussein.
articles.abstract: Chevron is preparing to acknowledge that it should have known oil kickbacks were being paid to Saddam Hussein.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chevron, the second-largest American oil company, is preparing to acknowledge that it should have known kickbacks were being paid to Saddam Hussein on oil it bought from Iraq as part of a defunct United Nations program, according to investigators.
articles.byline: By Claudio Gatti and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Alcoa Makes a Hostile Bid for Alcan
articles.snippet: The success of Alcoa’s hostile $27 billion takeover offer for the rival Alcan of Canada may rest as much with politicians as investors.
articles.abstract: The success of Alcoa’s hostile $27 billion takeover offer for the rival Alcan of Canada may rest as much with politicians as investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTREAL, May 7 — The success of Alcoa’s hostile $27 billion takeover offer for the rival Alcan of Canada may rest as much with politicians as investors.

articles.headline: Icahn Appears to Fall Short at Motorola
articles.snippet: The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn failed to get enough votes to be elected to Motorola’s board.
articles.abstract: The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn failed to get enough votes to be elected to Motorola’s board.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, May 7  The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn came to Chicago on Monday to attend Motorola’s shareholders meeting, with some expectation that he would get elected to the board.
